60fyfkeTVxclVOy8gk75kQ.text: With a group of friends, we went to the Barbary to try very tasty North African tapas. Although you can't make any bookings, we got a booking within an hour. We started with a deliciously crisp Naan e Barbari, then Zhug, Harrissa, Burnt & Pickled Chilli, pillowy Jerusalem Bagel, Msabacha Chickpeas and lush Baba Ghanoush. The Goat Goulash was good, as was the Chicken Abu Kalmash. The Octopus Mashawsha was amazing and the Cauliflower Jaffa Style while the Capsicum Haloumi and Broccoli & Black Tahini were good. Never had mozarella and goats cheese for dessert but it seemed to work. The 2015 Albarino was very fruity as was the Chignin

jvOhwdVA_ih6BrNvtp-A4g.text: Fantastic food, sister restaurant to Palomar, equally delicious. Baba ganoush, chicken liver were incredibly flavorful and memorable. Halva ice cream is highly recommended! Quick wait on a Sunday night and the staff was great!

XW8yJxCI6KgMXUAg8W9MOw.text: Finally made it to The Barbary yesterday, when my friend and I made plans to catch up over dinner on a weekday and decided to try our luck at the no reservations counter dining spot. It's by the same people who run The Palomar, but this has a focus on the Barbary Coast (i.e. North Africa). I would really only recommend this place if you are a group of two and are really good friends / dating, because otherwise the queueing and dining situation can be a bit much, and I have no idea how they would ever make room for an odd numbered party (seats only really open up in twos). We arrived at 7 pm and were given an estimated wait time of 1 hour, but we were able to wait along the wall (like you do at Barrafina) and have wine and appetizers, so it was not bad at all. We ordered grilled halloumi and octopus kibbeh, the latter of which was basically falafel made with octopus and bulgur wheat and very tasty. We were seated after 40 minutes, and once you order the food comes out really quickly - we were also done with our meal in 40 minutes! First we ordered naan and a pumpkin dip from the Baking & Grinding section. The naan was super thin but other than that, it was basically a typical flatbread, and the dip was very nice. For mains we got the grilled chicken thighs, monkfish, octopus, and cauliflower dishes, all of which I highly recommend. There wasn't a single bad dish in the group (and probably on the menu!). And as dessert we shared the hashcake, which is a pistachio tart served with whipped cream. Service was great, and it was so much fun to watch the open kitchen, with the chefs dancing to the music and clearly having a lot of fun. Would definitely recommend if you come here with the right dining companion!

gMhZPgiqQQnD7wayEVh3SA.text: Everything is good. Loved the beetroots and bulls heart tomatoes; both are especially good. Nice intimate atmosphere.

qURAX3I4H9gwcTAaCDA9Dg.text: Can't go wrong with Palomar and Barbary! Delicious food, great service, awesome atmosphere. Can't wait to go back!

MJnxBHQnqdW7NInc4U8VmQ.text: A resounding 5 stars and one of the best restaurants that I've been to in London. Be prepared to wait for a table, probably around 1-1.5 hours for dinner. Come with only 2-3 people in your party because it's a small restaurant and there are no tables, it's a U-shaped bar/counter seating. They don't take reservations, so just be prepared to wait (it's worth it!) and go early. While you wait, you can order a drink and 4 snacks (olives, haloumi fries, this mini pita bread stuffed with lamb & beef, and some spring rolls stuffed with salmon)TL;DR for what to order: If you're coming with 2 people, get 2 starters (definitely the mini pita bread with lamb + beef), one bread (naan or the Jersualem bagel), 2 dips, 1 meat dish, 1 vegetable dish, and 1 dessert. This should be enough food! The must-orders: mini pita bread, chicken, broccoli & black tahini, and the knafeh for dessert. My friend loved it so much he went there a second time that same week and said the pork neck is a must-order.I'd recommend getting either the haloumi fries or the mini pita bread -- we got both and they were delicious! I loved the mini pita bread stuffed with lamb and beef - I don't even like lamb but I liked these. They were stuffed and chargrilled and the most delicious little things I've ever had. Definitely getting these again. The haloumi fries were good, but I don't tend to like that kind of cheese as much - they were well spiced/seasoned and tasty, but I just didn't love these as much as the mini pita breads.I'd recommend getting either the naan or Jerusalem bagel with 2 dips/spreads. We picked the Jerusalem bagel which reminded me of a Turkish simit / almost like a pretzel covered with sesame seeds. Super fresh, served with some dukkah, and was really fluffy and soft. We picked the zhug / harissa dip and the pumpkin spread. Next time I might try the babaganoush or chickpeas. You can't really go wrong with any of these either. The pumpkin was a little sweet for my taste as a dip with the bread, but it was definitely something unique.For mains, we shared the chicken which was chargrilled and delicious, and a generous amount, served on top of some hummus. I'd highly recommend this to make sure you fill up with protein. We also got the broccoli with black tahini which was amazing -  I may have never had broccoli this good before. The chargrilled taste was spot on, and I loved the black tahini sauce.For dessert, the knafeh is hard to pronounce but everyone seems to get this dish. It's like a birds nest of phyllo dough stuffed with goat cheese and mozzarella cheese and with syrup - I don't like cheesy things that much for dessert, but this was amazing. I'd highly recommend this - it's super unique & delicious.I'll definitely be back here again - it's amazing. Watching the chefs cook everything in the open kitchen in the middle of the bar, the chargrilled taste of most things, and the freshness and uniqueness of the ingredients were great. I'd recommend this to anyone coming to London and can't wait to eat here again (and at Palomar). The price was fairly reasonable, I think it was around £60 for 2 people.

photos.caption: Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom. Knafeh
Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom. Menu
Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom. Snacks you can order while you wait

OfD6dBeCxbYdmIB3HK9tsw.text: Great food and friendly wait staff. Love the open kitchen and bar like seating. You got go watch everything being made in front of you. This is a tapas place so you order multiple dishes which is great because you get a taste of everything. Reservations can be made via their website but only for 12pm and 5pm. I showed up at 5pm on a Wednesday as a walk in and was able to be seated right away. It filled up quick after. Prob around 530 all seats were filled. This was a few min walk from the Palace Theaters where I was watching part 1 and part 2 of Harry potter. Great intermission dinner and was completely satisfied. Love their homemade nan the best witht theie various choices of dippings. Would so come back here when I get the chance.

photos.caption: Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom. Squid
Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom. Brocoli

FE9XPx_owVXEWrxWlKQQ3Q.text: Really nice meal.  Food is on point mostly.  Tiny place with great atmosphere.  Get there early or be ready to wait a bit.Highlights - Baba Ganoush, Chicken liver pate, Naan, Pluma Iberico was amazing (hard to go wrong), Jerusalem bagel.Only drawback was the monkfish.  Very strong flavors on this dish, took over the whole dish. Couldn't taste the fish or fennel, only spice.

RTl8GrM_v6kkVxSKNQWwbw.text: One of London's hottest middle eastern resto and lived up to the hype and consensus among critics and consumers. This place doesn't take reservations and is hidden away. Almost feels like it doesn't want to be found. Cannot make reservations here and place only has seating around the kitchen bar. Food, service, value, and ambience all great. Repeat: yes

i8oUtWmm73yCq32gfI9c0A.text: Food was so good, so flavorful!  The cauliflower was out of this world!  Also loved the Salmon Dukkah. All seating seems to be around the main bar.

photos.caption: Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom. Kitchen and bar
Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom. Beer
Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom. Eggplant

99YT6kuNPe18iAqqmrYOCg.text: Popped in, as the locals might say, on a Monday night to find a tiny but rustic and warm space.  A horseshoe shaped bar with seating for 24 left room for perhaps ten diners to queue and await their turn. This we did, having "Morrocan Cigars", which were delicious sticks of fried phyllo dough filled with hake, monkfish and cod.  A good start.We were seated and ordered a chicken entree and a monkfish entree, as well as some naan bread, a smoky baba ganoush and a spicy assortment of spreads.  It could not have been better.  Indeed, it is by far the tastiest dining I have discovered in London.If you like The Barbary, you might try "Sarma", in Somerville Massachusetts.  The two explore similar flavor spectra, but I'd give the Barbary the edge for achieving more through a smaller menu.

OmlUtsVNiONfRA-L2Bmipg.text: My friend Bryan was playing a gig at The Royal Opera House and I parlayed a quickie gig in Monte Carlo into an opportunity to celebrate a Clinton win, get reacquainted with London, and see my pal play this famous room. It was a brisk London night, dry.  Rain was in the forecast but it was waiting for the temperature to drop...colder...more unpleasant.  but who cared, the Donald would lose and order would be restored in 10 hours. We linked at The Opera House, got liquored at Balthazar, then made our way to Barbary, tucked away on the snazzy Neil's Yard, where we were seated immediately.  It's a 35 seat bar where they cook right in front of you. The Jerusalem Bagel and the BabaganoushThe Octopus The Pata NegraThe cauliflower Place is just awesome the flavors are spectacular, ask for Cecilia she's the best she'll do your order you will have a great time. Then Trump won the election and we were crushed. Spent the rest of the week arguing with stupid people and apologizing to smart people.

TvTiH6yGcKhUhAIT4VdrjA.text: I wanted to eat at The Barbary a second day in a row it was that great. The highlights were the Jerusalem Bagel and the Monkfish Chermoula. The Monkfish was grilled perfectly. We weren't really bothered by the short wait to be seated. We had a drink at the side bar during our wait and you can also order bites of food as well. I'm guessing there is a line as soon as they open at 5:00 to be seated, so timing wise, that first seating isn't probably finished until 5:45 or so.

lNdMN6RUClLmgdpNF6hBEA.text: The bartender at Palomar suggested this sister eatery.  As single diner, staff at both are great resources.My advice at The Barbary is - order what you've never heard of or can't pronounce.Then reap the reward of your adventure!

o-xRiHJVosFu5B0oZqmq-A.text: First visit today and really didn't know what to expect. First thing to say is the place is tiny. One U-shaped bar to sit at. Worked well as we were 3 ladies but might be more difficult to chat if in a group. Very welcoming and everyone we encountered was extremely friendly. Atmosphere is smart but relaxed. Food was absolutely delicious. We ate Pata Negra pork (the best!), octopus and lamb all cooked over charcoal, wonderful flat breads and various dips. A super balance of flavours and spicing. Looking forward to trying it again.

xESr5_gJG3_wsyGi97NBIw.text: To say that I can't get a meal like this in San Francisco would probably get my license revoked, but it's oh so depressingly true. Even something as simple as a bagel dipped in perfectly spiced harissa and schug tells me this place is special. The space is small without feeling exclusive and is oh so devastatingly stylish. I'm heading to its sister restaurant, Palomar, in a few days and can't wait!

KEnc9XP7eP2axDfelM1KZw.text: Great place - came here on a recommendation from the Bib Gourmand, and really did love the food. It's a small place, so expect quite a bit of a wait. Loved the brocollini and the lamb - had a phenomenal dessert as well, and waited with some halloumi fries. A really interesting mix of flavours that I hadn't experienced before. Great food. No complaints from me :-)

MTawOGDkdPmSkkR5I3a_aQ.text: Great atmosphere and service with even better food. Everything delicious and flavorful. We totally lucked into this place while walking in Covent Garden. It's definitely with the wait!

qr2GIA272fQxVSbe8eeP2g.text: Damn food at the Barbary is as good as it gets!!! Not fancy food, just honest to god fine delicious mouth watering food . Chef Asaf Granit making the best of Israeli signature dishes . I highly recommend the Jerusalem bagel , Ikra , Masbaha, baba ganosh and schog if you love spicy - from the first dishes. The crown Jewel from the meat dishes is the pata negra - pork neck steak - tender and flavorful. To sum up great place worth the wait !

J5J41B7V4ZnJ_M8aYp7IRw.text: Best meal I had in London and probably one of my favorite meals of all time. Ambiance was terrific, service was not just excellent, but they somehow manage to make you feel like your are at lively dinner party and the host has made a special meal just for you. It's so nice to be wowed and surprised like that again - thank you chefs of The Barbary.

ZzhK3-1Gh521oIGBA18IIg.text: Such a great little spot! Seating is limited (just a handful of stools around the bar) and no reservations, but the staff is very nice and it's very pleasant to stand and wait with a glass of wine with your friends before being seated. The food is delicious! Definitely get the fattoush, the pumpkin dipping spread, the naan, the haloumi fries and do NOT leave before you get dessert. The  Knafeh was AMAZING. This would be a great date spot or a catch-up with a friend. They prepare the food right in front of you which is a fun element. I wouldn't go with more than 3 people though - with the seating it would be difficult to talk to a large group.

RjKEL_oIlJZLdzJKpxAn_Q.text: After reading the reviews here and on Time Out we decided to give the Barbary a try & we were not disappointed.  We went on a Sunday evening over a bank holiday weekend so we didn't have to wait for long.  While waiting we enjoyed some delicious wine, olives, and fried halloumi.  The fried halloumi was out of this world.  Seating is all around the counter, not super comfortable but definitely cool to see everyone working the kitchen.  We were seated by the door so we had a nice breeze coming through thankfully.  We started with the Jerusalem bagel and baba ghanoush.  Next we had lamb and octopus, and then finished with the knafeh.  The knafeh was different (in a really great way) than any other dessert I've ever had.  Each course of our meal was more delicious than the next.  The service was friendly and our server gave us great recommendations.  After living in Europe for two years, our meal here was an absolute stand out.  I will definitely be here every time I'm visiting London.

C-0vRVNXc4pCn4aqFROJYg.text: Overpriced and Rude. First, the food they serve is very good. I liked the chickpeas, eggplant, and künefe (dessert). However, it is very overpriced. One of their staff was extremely rude to me. After I paid my bill, I wanted to use the bathroom, She stopped me at the back of the restaurant and asked where I am heading (perhaps thinking I'm a bum who breached the greeter/security at the front door). I expresses my desire to use the bathroom but she would not budge. I explained I just finished my dinner here. Her response: "Did you really now, which table?" I should mention there are no tables at this place, everyone sits around the bar, facing the cooking area. I pulled the receipt out of my pocket and finally she let me in with not much shame. I don't know what made her believe I don't belong there, my Mediterranean complexion, or slight beard, but then they serve food from my country, not to my people apparently. After paying 50 pounds, this was very insulting. If I wanted to pay loads of money to get insulted, I would go to a French restaurant :)

fAY0Or1U4T4AuaNzxlnkaQ.text: Fantastic food. Not cheap, but a fair price for such high quality in central London. Service was friendly and knowledgeable but perhaps overestimated the amount of food I needed.They don't take reservations but FYI I got there at noon on a weekday and there  were plenty of seats. By the time I left at 1pm, there was a short wait to get in.

RwmxxCm11pg4nTpX66y6Kw.text: Positively 5 stars!What do you look for in a great restaurant?* You feel welcome* Top quality food, beautifully prepared, beautifully presented.* Quick, incredibly pleasant, and well-informed service (thank you Sandra!)* Surprising combinations of tastes and textures - ginger and fennel ice cream!* Memorable experience - in this case, watching the ballet of 5 chefs in the open kitchen* Thinking about it the next day, and wishing The Barbary existed near where you liveThe Barbary - an excellent restaurant that provides an extra special experience.Bonus: Neal's Yard is located inn a very quaint courtyard with several walk-in massage practitioners. The whole neighborhood is pleasant to stroll.

zQwg8WuopU3iwIhgIAaHiw.text: The Barbary is a bit hidden along a smaller footpath, and dark and mysterious looking among the whimsical brightly painted walls and storefronts in the vicinity. I circled around the area for perhaps 10 minutes before I noticed the small plaque marking the hotspot. I stepped inside and put myself on the waitlist for a table for two, and the hostess said it would be max one hour. One must wait at the site, as opposed to leaving one's number. My friend and I ended up waiting about 90 minutes until two seats finally freed up. At this point, my stomach was ragingly empty and expectations high. From the beginning, it was clear that The Barbary sets itself apart by its unique physical layout and culture. In addition to being dark, inside they play loud American pop music that combines with the busy sounds of the kitchen, center stage in the little space. Our server arrived promptly and confidently offered his opinion on the best way to design our meal i.e. bread plus spread and 3-4 entrees, and even going so far as to recommend switching dishes based on redundant or complementary flavors. While the wait to get into the restaurant was arduous, the crew works like a well oiled machine and the dishes come out swiftly and logically once one orders.My favorite dishes were the halloumi and neck meat. They gave the halloumi nice thick grill marks and doused it with savory oils; it's reminiscent of string cheese in flavor but whereas I couldn't eat the latter in big bites--and don't even like cheese all that much in general--I found myself excitedly munching on chunks of halloumi. I definitely want to incorporate it in my pantry at home now. The next best dish was the petra negra neck meat. It was cooked medium rare yet had a nice char outside, and came with a sweeter sauce and soft roasted garlic.      The food is incredible, but the most memorable aspect of The Barbary was the staff. They were jamming to the music all night long, especially the woman bartender in front. They even took shots with the guests! When the bartender slid two tiny goblets to us with a wink, it certainly made me feel special. The way the 25 or so total seats form a ring around the chefs highlights the labor and technical skill that goes into cooking mastery. Watching them enjoy their work and interact with patrons made the night; it must be their love that makes the food taste so good.

photos.caption: Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom. Bay leaf ice cream and baklava
Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom. Monk fish
Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom. Lamb

jlH9D2sEMnjXBBv5l6YAtA.text: I came for lunch and luckily we were first in line. This place gets crowded fast as it's a 28 seat bar seating restaurant. Delicious from start to finish! Dishes are meant to be shared. We had naan, zhug, falafel, haloumi, cauliflower, chicken, lamb chop and monkfish. Dessert was sweet wine and baklava. So glad we made it here. Thanks for a wonderful lunch. Franck, our server, was great!

photos.caption: Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom

gvi6ZCVmOOAmpr8S0Ve4yA.text: Went here with a friend after making a reservation for 5pm about 2 weeks prior to arriving to London. Thankfully we did as this place only does a couple of seatings and it was packed.After perusing the menu, we decided to split a few items:Jerusalem bagel (4 stars): This was an interesting starter that was so buttery and had strong spices.Chickpeas (4 stars): The chickpeas were also very good. The natural flavor was there and then elevated a bit with some delicious spices.Cauliflower (4.5 stars): I am a huge fan of cauliflower and this dish did not disappoint--great flavors all around.Filled pastries (4.5 stars): I can't remember exactly what these were called, but they were stuffed with some sort of meat mixture (I think lamb and beef) and served with a chimichurri-type sauce. Overall, the dish was excellent.Black salmon (4.5 stars): The fish was cooked perfectly and the chef let the flavors of the fish speak for themselves. One of the best salmon dishes I've had.Pata Negra (5 stars): This was easily the best dish I had during the European trip. This is a must order as the meat is so tender and flavorful, unlike anything I've had before.Knafeh (4 stars): We finished with the signature dessert and it was a nice close to the meal, but nothing to write home about.Overall, this was one of the best meals I have had in a while and it did not break the bank. This place is unique in that all of the seating is around a bar and you get to see the food cooked right in front of you. The head chef even checked in with us several times throughout the meal, which was a nice touch. This is definitely a place worth checking out if you're in London.

photos.caption: Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom

j3ekCRfBZkD-rptytPBk3A.text: What a gem!  From location, to service and the food is extraordinary.  Had the Halloumi to start which has a nice kick to it.  The naan was perfect and made right before your eyes.  The chicken liver which I cant stand was pretty darn good. We had the chicken and lamb.  Everything was cooked to perfection.

JqO7C9EPchdKZGxc8hE55A.text: One word....AMAZING! Quite possibly one of the most savory meals of my life. Literally everything we ordered was soooooooooooo good! I loved the flavor profile of each dish. Such good thought went into each dish. The restaurant is small and only has approx 20 bar stools. You sit around the small kitchen and watch the chefs cook, which was cool to see. We came at 9pm and there happened to be two available seats at the bar and we only had to wait 2 min to be seated, that we were elated about because we had read that the wait times could be up to one hour. I guess it was good that we came so late in the evening. :)The Barbary will be on my first stop the next time we come to London. Better believe it!

photos.caption: Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom

xh_dHJtStpDMzJMRaO5k3w.text: Having been to Machneyuda and thoroughly enjoying the meal, it was a natural progression to try The Barbary. I took the advice of a few and went during lunch, to which I was seated immediately. Frank was super helpful and up for the challenge when I asked him to surprise me with a few dishes; no limitations. He brought me the ikra/pita, cauliflower, and pata negra; all of which were phenomenal accoutrements to one another.

photos.caption: Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom. Open kitchen
Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom. Ikra
Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom. Pata Negra

ROhTSm-dRYP4EMx701KSgQ.text: Come with a small group and be prepared to wait for an hour before getting called. The Barbary has a neat dining concept; everybody watches all the food being prepared while seated around the restaurant's U-shaped bar. It gets quite cozy, but the delicious food makes it all worth it.// Moroccan Cigars (£9) - 4 stars// Nan e Barbary (£3.50) - 5 stars// Baba Ghanoush (£4.50) - 5 stars// Octopus Mashawsha (£16.50) - 5 stars// Chicken Abu Kalmash (£13) - 4 stars

photos.caption: Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom. Nan e Barbary (3.50)
Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom. Baba Ghanoush (4.50)
Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom. Moroccan Cigars (9)

UWNjBJDH_tnplA1KHTmwmA.text: Excellent flavors! This place created magic in my mouth. Everything was great. The beets were my favorite. The cauliflower is a must. The salmon was also delicious - it's on the sweet side so if you don't like that maybe not for you. The hospitality was also great. Our host was so friendly and helpful with the menu. I felt like I escaped to a different place. There are only 24 or so seats so it's intimate which I liked.Go here!

gSSsJ0A8RzHQYQRHFLUAGw.text: The Barbary is hands down, one of the best middle eastern foods I've ever had... in my entire life. My boyfriend is middle eastern, and never has he tasted such well done lamb. The food was soooo exquisite, that I forgot to take pictures. It's a small little area, with a minimum wait of 15 minutes for 2 people. Their chefs do an impeccable job at seasoning EVERYTHING. It's all sharing portions- 4/5 dishes is about enough for 2 people. Trust me when I say, you'll be FLOORED with how amazing the textures and flavors this place has to offer. Bravo!

yoJffLvbHHdl_t0P3iIg9w.text: So rude waitress first I ask her if she have sitting for two she told that she will have after one hour and a half and left with out talking my answer. I asked her college if I can use the toilet she said yes and while I am going to the toilet the first waitress came and told me you cant use the toilet because its only for our costumers I told her I just asked you for a table she said no you cant. It was a very horrible experience I don't think it's a good place to chill.

59STOykShqtk3hnxWpD9tQ.text: Fave meal in London so far for this trip.  Such a fab intimate location on Neal's Yard, a tiny alley in Covent Garden, with 24 seats aroubd the kitchen area (every seat is chef's table :) ) Tasty gin and tonic to quench thirst after another ridiculously hot day in the city, chicken liver with hot English mustard and fresh naan, amazing Iberico ham (Patanegra) neck with date sauce (perfect balancr of salty and sweet, transcendent dish) and a cauliflower jaffa with tomato salsa, tahini, lemon and parsley, and a delightful knafeh (those tiny sweet pastry shards, balancing the goat and mozzarella cheese and finished in glorious butter)  Jane and Olga provided outstanding service and recommendations and I left very contented  The Barbary is such a cool, intimate venue, definitely worth a visit.

photos.caption: Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom. Killer meal at an awesome intimate location with great service

19jp627STZa8aGQLf4sECA.text: Love this hole in the wall place in Neals Yard. Great for a night out. We waited in queue since the restaurant is small and only has bar seating. Service was impeccable! All the dishes were delicious and portioned in small plates. We ordered the baba ganoush, Jerusalem bagel, tabbouleh, lamb chops, Jaffa cauliflower, and octopus. I could have that Jerusalem bagel everyday! Fun place to mingle but seating is first come first serve basis. Worth it!

photos.caption: Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom. Octo leg
Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom. Naan bread
Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom. Jerusalem bagel with zatar spices

ZosAmCWBp-5NN8KwSw6XSw.text: Oh man this was fantastic! Every single course was so memorable. I could definitely return here regularly and be amazed and astonished.

8F8xRWhGQV4IZ4PYTYodHA.text: In all my travels, this place holds the award for top 5 restaurants I have ever been to. So good we went 3 of the 5 nights we were I. London. Open kitchen concept, small, very friendly, creative epic food, and really just  all around wonderful... even the prices are fair! Note though... they are BUSY all the time. Getting a table is not easy, especially if you have a larger group. It's worth every penny though if you can get in!

fZlT5-uGz_qzoVegbbdOxw.text: The Barbary was an awesome dinner experience.  Definitely a top 3 restaurant I've had in Europe thus far.  It's located in a trendy ally.  The one room, sir around the bar concept while watching the food be prepared in cooked in the middle is very fun.  You could also see how efficiently and well the talented, young chef was running the kitchen.   I wish I could list all of the food I ordered, but I don't recall.  Everything was too notch.  This would the first place to stop in London.

photos.caption: Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom

VaHXGyKV2BUxUxBdJY8bBQ.text: The Barbary is amazing. I love the food at Machneyuda, and was excited to try another of the chef's restaurants on a trip to London.Waiting for seats was a tad annoying, but we ordered glasses of wine and posted up in a corner, so it honestly wasn't bad. We waited about 45 min in total, at 6pm on a Saturday, which was fine. Service was friendly and efficient, and it was fun to watch all of the food being made in front of you as you eat.The food was all incredible -- the naan and jerusalem bagel were great, as were all the dips we ordered for them. Lamb cutlet, cauliflower and halloumi were our remaining favorites.Highly recommend!

AwZLvVpr1OvXyljv9sxoGA.text: Great meal with an adventuresome menu. Only 24 seats around an open horseshoe shaped kitchen. I was a single and walked right in at 8. Expect to wait but great food.

qRDzKNUonklC0TWLC5yAEA.text: We snagged a 5:00 PM reservation a few weeks ahead of time. Well worth it! Tiny but powerful, with the kitchen is right in the center of the seating area so you can watch the magic. One of the most amazing meals I've ever had the pleasure of eating and definitely my best in London for sure. Staff was stellar and I even was treated to a little complimentary shot (it was my birthday). My server (I have a bad memory I apologize) was from Greece and he was awesome. Close to the theater since we were headed there afterwards. I will dreaming of this place until next time London! Thank you to the staff for making it such a memorable night.

LeSwncuTli-SROJlId9jHg.text: I went twice this week! I love their sister restaurant, The Palomar in Soho, so I had to try their new opening in Neal's Yard. It's really small with a U-shape bar counter seating. No reservations, so walk in early when they open. I first came at 12:15pm for lunch on a Thursday and didn't have to wait. Second time was 5:45pm on a Saturday night and waited 45 minutes. By the time we left, the wait was about 2 hours long at 8:00pm. Counter seats about 20 people I think. Service was attentive and so friendly. They're always refilling water, drinks, very quick food service, and all with a smile. Food was delicious! More tapas style than Palomar, but very beautifully presented and each dish was substantial. Get the haloumi fries, baba ganoush, naan, chicken, lamb, salmon, fattoush salad and aubergine. All were amazing. Salmon was on the smaller side and I think was the weakest dish.For dessert, I had the tart, which came with cream and was delicious. For drinks, the wine list is solid. Will definitely be back and often.

photos.caption: Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Barbary - London, United Kingdom

g7a7MiqUtzTnNRdAMJzGEA.text: Palomar is the better of the two sister restaurants but the menus and flavours are different and Barbary is awesome so plenty of reasons to go to both. The flavours are fresh and bright. The staff is friendly and informative. They make the meal fun. We had most of the things on the menu. All good. I would say explore.
